raw_text:
Prop Jones ready for hard graft
 
 Adam Jones says the Wales forwards are determined to set the perfect attacking platform for the backs by dominating the powerful France pack in Paris.
 
 The prop said: "If we get stuffed in the front five our backs have had it. "The mentality of the French is 'scrum, scrum, scrum'. We will see how good France are and the scrum is the key. "I just hope [the backs] carry on where they left off against Italy. It's just up to us in the forwards to win the ball and give them the opportunity." Wales have won two of their last three visits to Stade de France, having secured back-to-back wins under Graham Henry in 1999 and 2001. And with the likes of Shane Williams and Gavin Henson finding top form at the right time, Mike Ruddock's team is now one of international rugby's most potent attacking threats. "Gavin is ridiculously talented. He has been bouncing around the place this week, so he is up for it," warned Jones.
 
 France have been criticised for their uncharacteristic one-dimensional play in their victories over Scotland and France. Captain Fabien Pelous has acknowledged his side needs to show more attacking flair, but stressed the game with be won or lost up front. The lock believes the Welsh forwards are not big enough to trouble his side in the scrum or line-out, but Jones insisted his fellow front-row colleagues have nothing to fear.
 
 "Gethin [Jenkins] won't be intimidated tomorrow, none of us will," said Jones, who will be facing France for the first time. "We will go out there and front up and hopefully get the ball out to the backs. "Me and Gethin are quite young so it is good to have someone of Mefin's experience in there. "Mefin is a good thinker who puts things across. But what is the saying? If you are good enough you are old enough and Gethin certainly is. "He is a really good player and I imagine he will be on the Lions tour [to New Zealand this summer]."

Jones believes Wales have the firepower to win back-to-back games at Stade de France after beating Italy recently, and will be boosted by the presence of young forward Gethin Jenkins.

smollm:1.7b: The summary of the text above should preserve key ideas and details, while omitting unnecessary information.

The main points to focus on are:

1.
The prop's statement that France have a strong attacking threat due to their dominant pack in Paris.
The emphasis on the importance of winning the ball in the forwards, as this will give them an advantage over the backs.
The comment from Adam Jones that if they get stuffed in the front five, it will be difficult for the backs to win the game.
The mention of the Wales' ability to dominate the France pack and set up a good attacking platform for their backs.
The comment from Mike Ruddock's team about their ability to show more attacking flair and win the game.

Jones hopes to maintain this success while facing France, with Mefin's experience and plans for future travel in New Zealand being highlighted.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Wales forward line has been praised for their physicality but will face tough opposition from France's pack in the upcoming international Rugby Championship match.

With star performers Gaviñón, Pelous and other prominent players, France seeks to defend their win against Scotland with tenacious defense, while Wales is determined to dominate the powerhouse nation of France.
Wales coach Mike Ruddock feels that if they can get past France's top front-row players, such as Gaviñón and Pelous, they have the potential to unleash an explosive attacking threat against the pack.
However, Wales backline will need to perform better in the upcoming match for a successful outcome.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Wales' unbeaten run in recent visits to Paris has seen them score an impressive 19 tries at the expense of France.
The forwards, however, have been a cause for concern, with few able to dominate a pack that is known for its scrum-having capabilities.
Despite this, prop, Adam Jones, believes that his fellow front-rowers are not too concerned about the size of the opposition, but rather the mindset they need to bring against France.
Wales' key performance piece in the forward line will be given a tough time by French defenders and should have no fear in facing their formidable backs.
Meanwhile, Gethin Jenkins, an experienced lock, will be hoping to make his mark on the pitch as he continues his quest for the coveted Man of Steel award.

Wales have won two of their last three visits to Stade de France, with Mike Ruddock's team now one of international rugby's most potent attacking threats.
However, France has been criticized for one-dimensional play in their victories over Scotland and France, prompting captain Fabien Pelous to acknowledge the need for more attacking flair.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Prop Adam Jones, speaking for Wales forwards, emphasizes their determination to create an optimal attacking foundation for the backline by dominating France's powerful pack.
Jones highlights the importance of winning possession in the scrum, as it will set up opportunities for the skillful backs led by Shane Williams and Gavin Henson.
Wales has a history of success against France at Stade de France, with two victories under Graham Henry's leadership in 1999 and 2001.
France's captain Fabien Pelous acknowledges his team needs to improve their attacking flair but insists the game will be won or lost up front.

He believes Welsh forwards are not physically imposing enough in the scrum or line-out, a claim Jones refutes, stating that experienced players like himself and Gethin Jenkins will not be intimidated by the challenge.
Jones also praises Mefin as a seasoned thinker who mentors youngsters like Gethin Jenkins, emphasizing that Jenkins' skill level warrants his inclusion on potential Lions Tour to New Zealand.
